title: Chicken Parmesan Recipe (with Video)
description: For the best chicken Parmesan, try Chef John's version that's pan-fried and then baked, delivering impressive results with a crispier crust than most recipes.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Main Dishes Chicken Parmesan Chicken Parmesan 4.8 (5,020) 3,607 Reviews 1,646 Photos My version of chicken Parmesan is a little different than what they do in the restaurants, with less sauce and a crispier crust. By John Mitzewich John Mitzewich John Mitzewich — aka Chef John — has produced more than 1,500 cooking videos for Allrecipes. He's the actor, director, and screenwriter whose hands and voice confidently walk you through techniques. Allrecipes' editorial guidelines Updated on October 10, 2024 Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen Tested by Allrecipes Test Kitchen The Allrecipes Test Kitchen staff are a team of culinary pros who make and vet recipes using only equipment you'd find in a home kitchen. Staff credentials vary but include training at the Culinary Institute of America; kitchen stints in fine dining restaurants; and countless hours in the test kitchen itself. Meet the Allrecipes Test Kitchen Save Rate Print Share Add Photo 1,646 1,646 1,646 1,646 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 20 mins Additional Time: 10 mins Total Time: 45 mins Servings: 4 Yield: 4 servings Jump to Nutrition Facts Jump to recipe Dotdash Meredith Food Studios How to Make Chicken Parmesan That's Never Soggy Chicken Parmesan is no doubt the most popular non-pasta dish in Italian-American style restaurants. And while this delicious meal may seem fancy, it's actually pretty easy to make at home. In fact, chicken Parmesan is one of those meals that's often best made in your own kitchen. The main problem I have with most versions of Chicken Parmesan served in restaurants is that they drown the chicken in so much sauce and cheese that it ends up being a big soggy clump of chicken and cheese. But it doesn't have to be that way, not with this method. Unlike many restaurant preparations, this method doesn't overwhelm the chicken with sauce and cheese. The key to great non-soggy chicken Parmesan? Don't put any sauce under the chicken cutlets, just a little bit of sauce on top, so the breading stays relatively crisp. If you like a lot of sauce on your chicken Parmesan, that's fine, you can always serve extra sauce on the side. I also use some actual Parmesan cheese in this recipe! Curiously, most versions of chicken Parmesan only use mozzarella. Here, I'm going with a delicious mixture of fresh mozzarella, tangy Provolone and real Parmesan. Another little trick I employ here is to add some grated Parmesan to the breadcrumbs, which adds another layer of flavor. You'll fry the breadcrumb and Parmesan crusted chicken breasts just to golden brown before transferring them to a baking pan and adding sauce (but not too much!), cheese, and herbs. Okay, now let's break it down. Allrecipes Chef John's Top Tips for Making Chicken Parmesan Before we get to the recipe, here's your cheat sheet for making the best baked chicken Parmesan: Pound chicken to an even thickness: Pound the boneless chicken breasts out to an even width so they cook evenly. Basically, you're pounding the thick part down to the size of the thin part, about a half-inch thick.Don't skimp on seasoning: Salt and pepper the chicken well. Then don't bother with salting the flour and bread crumbs.Add Parmesan to the bread crumbs: Use Panko bread crumbs mixed with a little finely grated Parmesan cheese. When you fry the breaded chicken, the Parmesan will give it an extra crunch and exciting flavor.Rest before cooking: Before frying, let the breaded chicken sit on the counter for about 15 minutes to allow the coating to adhere to the chicken breast.Go easy on the sauce: THE KEY: Don't drown the poor breaded and fried chicken in sauce and smother it in cheese. Too much of a good thing is too much. You did all the work creating a crisp coating, why make it soggy with too much sauce and cheese?Make sure your oven is hot, hot, hot: Be sure your oven is completely preheated to 450 F. You'll want the cheese to brown slightly and the breading to crisp up before the chicken gets overcooked, and a nice hot oven is the way to go. Now find out the best wine to pair with your non-soggy, not-too-saucy baked chicken Parmesan. Enjoy! Allrecipes Community Tips and Praise "Perfectly delicious and beautiful just as instructed!" says angie. "As the video explains, too much sauce and/or cheese only takes away from the flavor — I learned this by experience. I suggest having additional sauce and/or cheese available if guests choose to add more on their plate, but personally think less is more in this case." "This recipe delivers!" raves deneice knotts. "This was SO easy. My chicken was juicy and crunchy plus the cheesy goodness. YUM!! My son said this 'slaps,' which means it's one of the best things he has ever tasted. Thanks! I'll make this again without being afraid of dry chicken." "A wonder of wonders!" raves Joe. "Watch the vid! Chef John has some cost-effective tips on flouring your chicken. As well as seasoning the chicken, instead of the flour, eggs, and panko. You will never do it any other way again. Two things I changed was to use my wife's spaghetti sauce. Of course. The other was to use Italian seasoning instead of fresh basil, which was not at hand. We WILL be making this again and again." Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 4 servings 4 skinless, boneless chicken breast halves salt and freshly ground black pepper to taste 2 large eggs 1 cup panko bread crumbs, or more as needed ¾ cup grated Parmesan cheese, divided 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour, or more if needed ½ cup olive oil for frying, or as needed ½ cup prepared tomato sauce ¼ cup fresh mozzarella, cut into small cubes ¼ cup chopped fresh basil ½ cup grated provolone cheese 2 teaspoons olive oil Directions Gather the ingredients. Preheat an oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C). Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Place chicken breasts between two sheets of heavy plastic (resealable freezer bags work well) on a solid, level surface. Firmly pound chicken with the smooth side of a meat mallet to a thickness of 1/2-inch. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Season chicken thoroughly with salt and pepper. Using a sifter or strainer; sprinkle flour over chicken breasts, evenly coating both sides Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Beat eggs in a shallow bowl and set aside. Mix bread crumbs and 1/2 cup Parmesan cheese in a separate bowl, set aside. Dip a flour-coated chicken breast in beaten eggs. Transfer breast to the bread crumb mixture, pressing crumbs into both sides. Repeat for each breast. Let chicken rest for 10 to 15 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Heat 1/2 inch olive oil in a large skillet on medium-high heat until it begins to shimmer. Cook chicken in the hot oil until golden, about 2 minutes per side. The chicken will finish cooking in the oven. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Transfer chicken to a baking dish. Top each breast with 2 tablespoons tomato sauce. Layer each chicken breast with equal amounts of mozzarella cheese, fresh basil, and provolone cheese. Sprinkle remaining Parmesan over top and drizzle each with 1/2 teaspoon olive oil. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Bake in the preheated oven until cheese is browned and bubbly and chicken breasts are no longer pink in the center, 15 to 20 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 165 degrees F (74 degrees C). Dotdash Meredith Food Studios Chef's Notes Use high-quality prepared tomato sauce for a better result. You may substitute pesto or dried Italian herbs of your choice for basil or omit entirely. I Made It Print 11,054 home cooks made it! Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Chicken Parmesan 01 of 1,646 Photo by  Dotdash Meredith Food Studios 02 of 1,646 Photo by  LUVJEZUZ 04/09/2025 A keeper! Crowd-pleaser Family favorite I used GF breadcrumbs GF flour as we eat gluten free. Used thinly sliced breast from Aldi. Added Italian seasoning and dried basil to breadcrumb mixture. Used shredded Italian blend cheese on top and jarred sauce. Very good !! 03 of 1,646 Photo by  HRHPearl 03/26/2025 A keeper! Easy to follow Worth the effort Family favorite Made exactly as written. 04 of 1,646 Photo by  Dave Thompson 01/30/2025 I cooked everything to the directions.The only thing I changed was adding dry italian seasoning and it is delicious. I got my chicken breast from albertsons.And cut them in half. Oh, I also used avocado oil.Thank you! 05 of 1,646 Photo by  DREGINEK 09/12/2024 I am not a Chicken Parmesan fan but my man is and he raved and wowed about this!! I was also impressed. It’s a small labor of love but worth it! And while it feels like a lot of steps, they are actually pretty simple. The only change; I didn’t have fresh basil so I added about a tsp of dried to the panko/parmesan mix. Wish I had fresh basil but my adaptation worked. Served over a simple butter noodle recipe from this site. Great! And I have already been asked to make again! Sure will! Thanks Chef John! 06 of 1,646 Photo by  Lori Kempen 09/11/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Worth the effort Family favorite I will definitely do this again. I was rushing a bit and didn’t have the tomato sauce on hand so substituted onions sautéed in butter, plus two chopped tomatoes with salt and oregano. My whole family loved it, even the picky ones. It used up a lot of dishes, so there was sincere regret on the part of the washer. I live overseas in a heavily taxed country— on imports and in country industry—so I’ll probably always make my tomato sauce—I would drain it next time as it was slightly mushy in places under the cheese. I’ll try to figure out how to have less dishes next time. I left it in a little longer than necessary, but it was delicious, even though it didn’t look nearly as nice as Chef John’s. Not a scrap was left.Update: I tried it again and cooked the tomato sauce in the pan, wiped it out and filled it with oil. I laid the fried chicken on paper towels so that when I baked it, the lack of grease made it way easier to clean. I rinsed the dipping bowls (eggs, flour, etc) right away. My family all loved it, and cleanup was a breeze. 07 of 1,646 Photo by  PlushPie8719 09/09/2024 Only made 2 and the cast-iron skillet worked beautifully. Delicious. 08 of 1,646 Photo by  YellowGlass6699 08/29/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow Family favorite Worth the effort This was my first time making this dish and it came out amazing. I will definitely add more cheese and I used the Italian Style bread crumbs. 09 of 1,646 Photo by  allisoba 08/20/2024 A keeper! Worth the effort Easy to follow Great flavors Terrific!! I made this as directed. The tomato sauce I used was Mid’s bolognese flavor. Husband said “don’t change a thing “. I will definitely use this recipe again. Delicious. Thanks so much. 10 of 1,646 Photo by  IcyAle9843 07/08/2024 A keeper! Great flavors Easy to follow Worth the effort Crowd-pleaser Family favorite I always enjoy this recipe. 1 2 3 4 5 Next You’ll Also Love Best Chicken Parmesan 23 Ratings The Best Parmesan Chicken Bake 2,211 Ratings New & Improved Chicken Parmesan 85 Ratings Baked Parmesan-Crusted Chicken 448 Ratings Parmesan Sesame Chicken 54 Ratings Quick Air Fryer Chicken Parmesan 2 Ratings Brad's Slow Cooker Chicken Parmesan 43 Ratings Chicken Parmesan with Zucchini Pasta 44 Ratings Make-Ahead Freezer Chicken Parmesan 9 Ratings Easy Ranch-Parmesan Chicken 1 Rating Spinach Chicken Parmesan 600 Ratings Breaded Parmesan Chicken 343 Ratings Tomato Chicken Parmesan 2,307 Ratings Quick Crispy Parmesan Chicken Breasts 357 Ratings My Chicken Parmesan 48 Ratings Simply Parmesan Chicken 470 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: John Mitzewich
instructions: Gather the ingredients. Preheat an oven to 450 degrees F (230 degrees C). Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Place chicken breasts between two sheets of heavy plastic (resealable freezer bags work well) on a solid, level surface. Firmly pound chicken with the smooth side of a meat mallet to a thickness of 1/2-inch. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Season chicken thoroughly with salt and pepper. Using a sifter or strainer; sprinkle flour over chicken breasts, evenly coating both sides Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Beat eggs in a shallow bowl and set aside. Mix bread crumbs and 1/2 cup Parmesan cheese in a separate bowl, set aside. Dip a flour-coated chicken breast in beaten eggs. Transfer breast to the bread crumb mixture, pressing crumbs into both sides. Repeat for each breast. Let chicken rest for 10 to 15 minutes. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Heat 1/2 inch olive oil in a large skillet on medium-high heat until it begins to shimmer. Cook chicken in the hot oil until golden, about 2 minutes per side. The chicken will finish cooking in the oven. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Transfer chicken to a baking dish. Top each breast with 2 tablespoons tomato sauce. Layer each chicken breast with equal amounts of mozzarella cheese, fresh basil, and provolone cheese. Sprinkle remaining Parmesan over top and drizzle each with 1/2 teaspoon olive oil. Dotdash Meredith Food Studios;Bake in the preheated oven until cheese is browned and bubbly and chicken breasts are no longer pink in the center, 15 to 20 minutes. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read at least 165 degrees F (74 degrees C). Dotdash Meredith Food Studios
